Comment: This game features an early blunder by white, and a recovery leading to a fairly quick victory for white.
The French opening, played unreflectively by both parties. I opted for a3 without much thought, and relying heavily on a games database. Thinking on my own, I may have played Ng3 instead.

No way to add a third defender to the knight. Only option is to go down fighting.
And lose a pawn. The king now has to give up castling rights. Virtually none of the minor pieces are developed. At this point I considered resigning, but somehow or other, continued playing.

Trying to move the king to a safe position.
Perhaps black should have pressed his advantage by attacking the e5 square with f6. It removes a strategically placed pawn and begins to open up a file for his light square bishop.

Not sure what black's plan is. My only concern is to get the knight and bishop out of their starting positions to connect the rooks.
